heading: 1.1 Preliminaries
text:

\[
B_r(x)=\{y\\mathbb{R}^d :|y−x|<r\}.
\]
subset \(E\subset\mathbb{R}^d\) open every \(x\E\) exists \(r>0\) \(B_r(x)\subset E\). definition, set closed complement open.note (necessarily countable) union open sets open, general intersection finitely many open sets open. similar statement holds class closed sets, one interchanges roles unions intersections.set \(E\) bounded contained ball finite radius. bounded set compact also closed. Also, closure \(\overline{E}\) \(E\) consists union \(E\) limit points. boundary set \(E\), denoted \(\partial E\), set points closure \(E\) interior \(E\).Note closure set closed set; every point \(E\) limit point \(E\); set closed contains limit points. Finally, closed set \(E\) perfect \(E\) isolated points.Lemma 1.1  rectangle almost disjoint union finitely many rectangles, say \(R=\bigcup_{k=1}^NR_k\), 
\[
|R|=\sum_{k=1}^N |R_k|
\]Lemma 1.2  \(R,R_1,\dots,R_N\) rectangles, \(R\subset\bigcup_{k=1}^NR_k\), 
\[
|R|\leq\sum_{k=1}^N |R_k|
\]Every open subset \(\cal{O}\) \(\mathbb{R}\) can written uniquely countable union disjoint open intervals.Every open subset \(\cal{O}\) \(\mathbb{R}^d\), \(d\geq 1\), can written uniquely countable union almost disjoint closed cubes.Cantor set \(\cal{C}\) definition intersection \(C_k\)’s:
\[
\mathcal{C}=\bigcap_{k=0}^{\infty}C_k.
\]set \(\cal{C}\) empty, since end-points intervals \(C_k\) (\(k\)) belong \(\cal{C}\).
Despite simple construction, Cantor set enjoys many interesting topological analytical properties. instance, \(\cal{C}\) closed bounded, hence compact. Also, \(\cal{C}\) totally disconnected: given \(x,y\\cal{C}\) exists \(z\\\cal{C}\) lies \(x\) \(y\). Finally, \(\cal{C}\) perfect: isolated points.terms cardinality Cantor set rather large: countable. Since can mapped interval \([0,1]\), Cantor set cardinality continuum. heading: 1.2 The exterior measure
text:
Definition 1.1  \(E\) subset \(\mathbb{R}^d\), exterior measure \(E\) 
\[
m_{\ast}(E) = \inf\sum_{j=1}^{\infty}|Q_j|,
\]
infimum taken countable coverings \(E\subset \bigcup_{j=1}^{\infty}Q_j\) closed cubes. general \(0\leq m_{\ast}(E)\leq \infty\).suffice allow finite sums definition \(m_{\ast}(E)\). quantity obtained one considered coverings \(E\) finite unions cubes general larger \(m_{\ast}(E)\).One can, however, replace coverings cubes, coverings rectangles; coverings balls.Example 1.1  exterior measure closed cube equal volume.Example 1.2  exterior measure open cube equal volume.Example 1.3  exterior measure rectangle equal volume.Example 1.4  Cantor set \(\cal C\) exterior measure 0.

heading: 1.2.1 Properties of the exterior measure
text:
definition know :
- every \(\epsilon>0\), exists covering \(E\subset \bigcup_{j=1}^{\infty}Q_j\) 
\[
\sum_{j=1}^{\infty}m_{\ast}(Q_j)\leq m_{\ast}(E)+\epsilon.
\]Proposition 1.1  (Monotonicity) \(E_1\subset E_2\), \(m_{\ast}(E_1)\leq m_{\ast}(E_2)\).(Countatble sub-additivity) \(E= \bigcup_{j=1}^{\infty}E_j\), \(m_{\ast}(E)\leq\sum_{j=1}^{\infty}m_{\ast}(E_j)\).\(E\subset\mathbb{R}^d\), \(m_{\ast}(E)=\inf m_{\ast}(\cal O)\), infimum taken open sets \(\cal O\) containing \(E\).
Proof.

suffices prove \(m_{\ast}(E)\geq \inf m_{\ast}(\cal O)\). Notice closed cube \(Q_j\), exists open set \(S_j\) contains \(Q_j\) \(|S_j|\leq (1+\epsilon)|Q_j|\) fixed \(\epsilon>0\).
\(E=E_1\cup E_2\),\(d(E_1,E_2)>0\), 
\[
m_{\ast}(E)=  m_{\ast}(E_1)+  m_{\ast}(E_2).
\]set \(E\) countable union almost disjoint cubes \(E=\bigcup_{j=1}^{\infty}Q_j\), 
\[
m_{\ast}(E) = \sum_{j=1}^{\infty}|Q_j|.
\]
Proof.

Consider constructing family cubes finite distance one another, can use proposition 4.

heading: 1.3 Measurable sets and the Lebesgue measure
text:
notion measurability isolates collection subsets \(\mathbb{R}^d\) exterior measure satisfies desired properties, including additivity (fact countable additivity) disjoint unions sets.number different ways defining measurability, turn equivalent. Probably simplest intuitive following: subset \(E\) \(\mathbb{R}^d\) Lebesgue measurable, simply measurable, \(\epsilon > 0\) exists open set \(\cal O\) \(E\subset\cal O\) 
\[
m_{\ast}(\mathcal{O}-E) ≤ \epsilon.
\]
compared Proposition 1.1 3, holds sets \(E\). E measurable, define Lebesgue measure (measure) \(m(E)\) 
\[
m(E)=m_{\ast}(E).
\]Immediately definition, find:Proposition 1.2  Every open set \(\mathbb{R}^d\) measurable.\(m_{\ast}(E)=0\), \(E\) measurable. particular, \(F\) subset set exterior measure \(0\), \(F\) measurable.countable union measurable sets measurable.Closed sets measurable.
Proof.

Since closed set \(F\) can written union compact sets, say \(F=\bigcup_{k=1}^{\infty}F\cap B_k\), \(B_k\) denotes closed ball radius \(k\) centered origin, suffices prove compact sets measurable.
complement measurable set measurable.
Proof.

every positive integer \(n\) choose open set \(\cal O_n\) \(E\subset \cal O_n\) \(m_{\ast}(\mathcal{O_n}-E)\leq 1/n\). Notice 
\[
  (E^c-\bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty}\mathcal{O_n^c}) \subset(\mathcal{O_n}-E)
\]
\(E^c\) measurable since \(E^c=(E^c-\bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty}\mathcal{O_n^c})\cup \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty}\mathcal{O_n^c}\).
countable intersection measurable sets measurable.prove fourth proposition, need following lemma.Lemma 1.3  \(F\) closed, \(K\) compact, sets disjoint, \(d(F,K)>0\).Theorem 1.1  \(E_1,E_2,\dots\), disjoint measurable sets, \(E=\bigcup_{j=1}^{\infty}E_j\), 
\[
m(E)=\sum_{j=1}^{\infty}m(E_j).
\]Corollary 1.1  Suppose \(E_1,E_2,...\) measurable subsets \(\mathbb{R}^d\).\(E_k \nearrow E\), \(m(E) =\lim_{N\\infty}m(E_N)\).\(E_k \searrow E\) \(m(E_k)<\infty\) \(k\), \(m(E) =\lim_{N\\infty}m(E_N)\).Theorem 1.2  Suppose \(E\) measurable subset \(\mathbb{R}^d\). every \(\epsilon>0\):exists open set \(\cal O\) \(E\subset \cal O\) \(m(\mathcal{O}-E)\leq\epsilon\).exists closed set \(F\) \(F\subset E\) \(m(E-F)\leq\epsilon\).\(m(E)\) finite, exists compact set \(K\) \(K\subset E\) \(m(E-K)\leq \epsilon\).\(m(E)\) finite, exists finite union \(F=\bigcup_{j=1}^NQ_j\) closed cubes 
\[
m(E\triangle F)\leq \epsilon.
\]
Proof.

Choose family closed cubes \(\{Q_j\}_{j=1}^{\infty}\) 
\[
  E\subset \bigcup_{j=1}^{\infty}Q_j \text{ } \sum_{j=1}^{\infty}|Q_j|\le m(E) +\epsilon/2.
\]
Since \(m(E) <\infty\), series converges exists \(N>0\) \(\sum_{j=n+1}^{\infty}|Q_j|\le \epsilon/2\). \(F=\bigcup_{j=1}^NQ_j\), 
\[
\begin{aligned}
m(E\triangle F) &= m(E-F)+m(F-E)\\
&\le m\left( \bigcup_{j=1}^{\infty}Q_j - F\right)+m\left( \bigcup_{j=1}^{\infty}Q_j-E\right)\\
&\le m\left( \bigcup_{j=n+1}^{\infty}Q_j\right)+ m\left( \bigcup_{j=n+1}^{\infty}Q_j\right)-m(E)\\
&\le \sum_{j=n+1}^{\infty}|Q_j|+\sum_{j=1}^{\infty}|Q_j|-m(E)\\
&\le \epsilon.
\end{aligned}
\]

heading: 1.4.2 Approximation by simple functions or step functions
1.4.3 Littlewood’s three principles
text:
Theorem 1.6  (Egorov) Suppose \(\{f_k\}_{k=1}^{\infty}\) sequence measurable functions defined measurable set \(E\) \(m(E)<\infty\), assume \(f_k\f\) .e. \(E\) \(f_1,f_2,\dots,f_k,f\) finite valued .e. \(E\). Given \(\epsilon>0\), can find closed set \(A_{\epsilon}\subset E\) \(m(E-A_{\epsilon})\le \epsilon\) \(f_k\f\) uniformly \(A_{\epsilon}\).Remark. Note \(f_1,f_2,\dots,f_k,f\) finite valued .e. \(E\). Indeed, satisfied, construct \(\{E_k^n\}_{k=1}^\infty\) \(E_k^n\nearrow E\). counterexample 
\[
f_k(x)=\begin{cases}
k&|x|\le k,\\
\infty &|x|>k
\end{cases}
\]
\(f(x)=\infty\) \(\mathbb{R}\).Remark. Note \(m(E)<\infty\) easy construct counterexamples \(m(E)=\infty\). Indeed, \(m(E)=\infty\), find \(k_n\) \(m(E-E_{k_n}^n)<1/2^n\) since \(m(E-E_{k_n}^n)=m(E)-m(E_{k_n}^n)\).Theorem 1.7  (Lusin) Suppose \(f\) measurable finite valued .e. \(E\) \(E\) finite measure. every \(\epsilon>0\) exists closed set \(F_{\epsilon}\), 
\[
F_{\epsilon}\subset E, \text{ }m(E-F_{\epsilon})\le \epsilon
\]
\(f|_{F_{\epsilon}}\) continuous.

heading: 2.1.2 Stage two: bounded functions supported on a set of finite measure
text:
Lemma 2.1  Let \(f\) bounded function supported set \(E\) finite measure. \(\{\varphi_n\}_{n=1}^\infty\) sequence simple functions bounded \(M\), supported \(E\), \(\varphi_n(x)\f(x)\) .e. \(x\), :limit \(\lim_{n\\infty}\int\varphi_n\) exists.\(f=0\) .e., limit \(\lim_{n\\infty}\int\varphi_n\) equals 0.bounded function \(f\) supported sets finite measure, define Lebesgue integral 
\[
\int f=\lim_{n\\infty}\int\varphi_n.
\]
\(\{\varphi_n\}\) sequence simple functions satisfying: \(|\varphi_n|\le M\), \(\varphi_n\) supported support \(f\), \(\varphi_n(x)\f(x)\) .e. \(x\) \(n\) tends infinity.Next, must show \(\int f\) independent limiting sequence \(\{\varphi_n\}\) used, order integral well-defined. Suppose \(\{\psi_n\}\) another sequence simple functions satisfies properties . , \(\eta_n = \varphi_n- \psi_n\), sequence \(\{\eta_n\}\) consists simple functions bounded \(2M\), supported set finite measure, \(\eta_n\0\) .e. \(n\) tends infinity. Applying lemma find
\[
\lim_{n\\infty}\int \varphi_n =\lim_{n\\infty}\int \psi_n+\lim_{n\\infty}\int \eta_n=\lim_{n\\infty}\int \psi_n
\]
desired.Proposition 2.2  Suppose \(f\) \(g\) bounded functions supported sets finite measure. following properties hold.Linearity.Additivity.Monotonicity.Triangle inequality.Theorem 2.1  (Bounded convergence theorem)

heading: 2.1.4 Stage three: non-negative functions
text:
case function \(f\) define Lebesgue integral 
\[
\int f =\sup_g\int g.
\]Proposition 2.3  integral non-negative measurable functions enjoys following properties:Linearity.Additivity.Monotonicity.\(g\) integrable \(0\le f\le g\), \(f\) integrable.\(f\) integrable, \(f(x)<\infty\) .e. \(x\).\(\int f=0\), \(f(x)=0\) .e. \(x\).
Proof.

just prove first assertion. Let \(\varphi\), \(\psi\) \(\eta\) non-negative functions bounded supported sets finite measure, \(\varphi\le f\), \(\psi\le g\) \(\eta\le f+g\), \(\varphi+\psi\le f+g\). Consequently,
\[
\int f+ \int g\le \int (f+g).
\]
hand, define \(\eta_1=\min(f(x),\eta(x))\) \(\eta_2=\eta-\eta_1\), 
\[
\int \eta=\int(\eta_1+\eta_2)=\int \eta_1+\int \eta_2\le\int f+ \int g,
\]
means 
\[
\int (f+g)\le \int f+ \int g.
\]
Lemma 2.2  (Fatou) Corollary 2.1  Suppose \(f\) non-negative measurable function, \(\{f_n\}\) sequence non-negative measurable functions \(f_n(x) \le f(x)\) \(f_n(x)\f(x)\) .e. \(x\). 
\[
\lim_{n\\infty}\int f_n=\int f.
\]Corollary 2.2  (Monotone convergence theorem) Suppose \(\{f_n\}\) sequence non-negative measurable functions \(f_n(x) \nearrow f(x)\). 
\[
\lim_{n\\infty}\int f_n=\int f.
\]Corollary 2.3  Consider series \(\sum_{k=1}^{\infty}a_k(x)\), \(a_k(x)\ge 0\) measurable every \(k\ge 1\). 
\[
\int \sum_{k=1}^{\infty}a_k(x)\ dx =\sum_{k=1}^{\infty}\int a_k(x)\ dx.
\]

heading: 2.2 The space \(L^1\) of integrable functions
text:
integrable function \(f\) \(\mathbb{R}^d\) define \(L^1\)-norm \(f\),
\[
\|f\|=\|f\|_{L^1}=\|f\|_{L^1(\mathbb{R}^d)}=\int_{\mathbb{R}^d}|f|.
